headline: Cream Cheese Sugar Cookies
description: These cream cheese sugar cookies are soft and chewy and certainly simple to make. Chilling the dough makes it easier to roll and cut these cookies.

video.description: Beautiful and delicate looking cream cheese sugar cookies will delight your taste buds and your guests will love them!
video.name: Cream Cheese Sugar Cookies

name: Cream Cheese Sugar Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Beat sugar, butter, cream cheese, egg yolk, salt, almond extract, and vanilla in a large bowl with an electric mixer until smooth. Gradually mix in flour.
Divide dough into thirds and form each piece into a disc. Wrap tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate, 8 hours or overnight.
When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Working with one disc at a time, roll dough on a lightly floured surface to a thickness of 1/8 inch; keep other discs refrigerated until ready to roll.
Cut dough into desired shapes with lightly floured cookie cutters. Place cookies 1 inch apart onto ungreased cookie sheets.
Bake in the preheated oven until cookies are light golden brown, 7 to 10 minutes, switching racks halfway through. Remove from the oven and transfer to wire racks.
Repeat Steps 4 to 6 to bake remaining batches.

review.reviewBody: Love this recipe but what I did was used it for the bottom of my New York Cheesecake instead of the gram chacker it normally calls for

I love this recipe so much. It's simple and the ingredients are basic so I always have them. My grown kids and grandkids always ask for these cookies. I made them exactly to recipe and continue to do so for many years now.
Delicious! Super soft cookie.

These are amazing. Changed flavor profile to fit the Holiday I made them for. Add orange zest and extract for Christmas, cinnamon for Thanksgiving. Very versatile cookie recipe. Definitely in my "go to" recipe book

So easy. I was out of almond extract so I used a full tsp of vanilla and sprinkled the cookies with granulated sugar just before putting in oven and baking. Also I didn’t ice them. The granulated sugar resulted in just the right amount of sweetness. ??????????
These turned out great! Easy to make and great tasting.

I used the modified recipe from Cherish, posted in the comments. It turned out great. I divided into 5 balls, then tried different ways to roll it out. The best method I found was freezing the dough, then letting it warm up slightly to make it easier to roll. I have a granite counter, but I found it easier to roll out the dough between 2 pieces of parchment paper. I recommend 1/4 inch thick, as this recipe does not rise, and 1/8” was too thin and brittle. I frosted with Royal icing.

This is a fabulous recipe as is but I change up the extracts to fit different holidays. For example I will use strawberry extract instead of the almond for making Valentine cookies. I have also used Lemon extract, peppermint extract, root beer extract and rum extract in place of the almond and still use vanilla. They are all so good!
Delicious

Just made the dough at the moment waiting for it to chill for 8 hours, tried a little nibble of the dough because I couldn't help my self due to the fact that I usually can't make deserts correctly the first time but hey practice makes perfect, anywho cant wait to role the dough and cut, bake then eat.
At first the dough was too crumbly and then after I added milk it turned to wet, but after I added more flour it was perfect

Turned out amazing! First time making cookies ever and decorating myself. Its easy (little time consuming) portioning is a bit off i feel but thats fine I ended up with a tray and a half. As for anyone saying they are bland... your supposed to ice them or put sprinkles.

I made these like a week ago, came out great I think I messed it up a little bit everyone still ate them and were gone in 2 days. I did make a change in the coloring since I am from New Jersey I made the claws Blue in honor of our blue claw crabs. I would recommend this to anyone!

The recipe is super simple. I made it just as instructed but only baked 12 cookies. Froze the rest for later. I didn’t decorate the cookie nor sprinkled with sugar and that left my cookies missing something. Will finish the next batch with something...
The cookies were excellent! Soft and moist and so easy to make!
Great recipe. Grand kids loved decorating these cookies.
These are easy, and the BEST sugar cookies ever! I’ll never use any other recipe.
the dough tastes good after 8 hours of refrigeration, but even using a tad less flour it was too flaky and unable to stick together. A bust, had to toss it out.
It was good. I added lemon and almond extract. Good cookie.
These cookies are great! We rolled them out thicker and cooked them a little longer. They were great cookies for decorating.
I followed a few of the suggestions in the comments. I will definitely make them again.
My nine year old daughter was able to follow the instructions. She really enjoyed making them.

These cookies turned out great. The only thing I added was the seeds of one vanilla bean to the creamed mixture...just to deepen the vanilla flavor, before I added the flour. otherwise I followed the recipe as is. They were yummy and I received great compliments. Next time, I would add some salt crystals to the cookies. I also cut these out directly on the baking mat, so that I didn't lose the flavor to the flour that is usually used to rollout and cut the cookies. Next time, I would replace the almond with lemon juice or more vanilla...but that's a personal preference - I just don't like almond extract. My in-law who is a good baker wanted the recipe and her son loved them.

This is the sugar cookie recipe I have used for years. It's from an old Pillsbury baking book. Probably because I'm so used to it, I don't think it's all that hard to work with. A couple of tricks, as the dough is a bit soft, is to flour the rolling pin, and use a very thin spatula to get the cookies from the workspace to the baking sheet. I always frost with cream cheese frosting.

These cookies are sensational. I made the recipe as is and cut it in coin shapes which I sprinkled with powdered sugar. The tangy cream cheese made this cookie unusual for a sugar cookie. I followed the suggestion of rolling it on a bench flour mix with sugar. I combined 50% sugar and 50% flour. It does make a difference. Also, my personal suggestion would be use a flexible bread maker's bench scraper to work it. It will be your BFF once you use it with dough that has the tendency to become sticky. They are inexpensive and save you a lot of tears of disappointment. A granite plaque also might help you as it tends to stay naturally cold making it easier to work sticky dough.

Tasty but do not hold their shape during the baking process plus you need to only roll to 1/4 inch not 1/8 - they completely lose their shape if only 1/8 inch thick. Also 375 is too hot - - the edges burn and the center is almost raw. I am so disappointed - I spent too much time and money on these and now I have no sugar cookies for the kids.
I normally HATE sugar cookies but after baking these for Christmas they have become one of my favorites!
They came out PERFECT!! Best sugar recipe I've ever used. You can eat them with or without icing and still delish
Perfect sugar cookie recipe and really easy. I cut them a little thick, they retain their shape & size nicely. They don’t spread or puff up and sink. Taste delicious too! Will always use this recipe.
We made these cookies however used only egg white no yolk
I used marscapone instead of cream cheese. They were excellent
These are the best sugar cookies ever! I added them to my collection so I will never have to look for them again. Everyone loved them.
I've made these every Christmas for the past few years and they are amazing!
Dough is a little hard to work with because it is so firm when cold and sticky when warm. Can only work with in very small amounts. The family thinks they taste great tho and they are very soft

I think some of the confusion is because the recipe states "one 3 ounce package". However, a typical package of cream cheese is 8 ounces. So, which is it really from the original recipe writer......3 or 8 ounces? At any rate, I'm not going to say what I did with the recipe.....any sugar cookie is going to taste better than stale fruitcake. Happy holidays to all cookie makers the world over! xoxoxoxo.
No changes. I love the almond flavouring in it.

I followed the suggestions of another user by increasing the cream cheese to 8oz and sugar to 1 1/2 cups; they turned out wonderful! I chilled the dough for approx 2 hours; they rolled out beautifully and maintained their shape while baking. This is my new go-to recipe for cut-outs!
These aren’t bad, but I found them too salty—either that or you can really taste the baking powder/soda. They did stay chewy and had a nice texture, though!
I would put 8oz cream cheese and 2 1/2 cups flour

These reviews are so irritating.. we just want to know how the original recipe turned out. You want to add your own variation, create your own new recipe post. 


Anyway, I ignored all of the reviews and their variations and went with the original. Cookies turned out fabulous! I did make a royal icing to top them but they were good alone. Taste like a cheesecake in a cookie! Soft , and stayed soft the next day even leaving them sit on a plate overnight. Perfect recipe, just what I was looking for!

Good but not as good as original sugar cookies with orange zest. 
Easy to make.

great cookie! i added a whole egg instead of just the yolk. easy to roll out and cut beautifully. could easily be flavored with other extracts for a change. i decorated with royal icing and sprinkles for valentines day. definitely wil be my "go to" cookie recipe for all bake-a-thons!

I love the suggested changes cookie. Things I would like to add to help an amatures like me. Mix 8oz cream cheese, 1 1/2 cups of sugar and 1 cup unsalted butter. Mix till properly creamed... the sugar becomes one with the butter. Then add 1 egg, 1 teaspoon vanilla and 1/2 tsp of almond extract mix again. Then add 3 1/2 cups of flour 1 tsp of baking powder. I also did a chocolate raspberry filling. Heat a 1/4 of whip cream to just a boil take off heat then add 3/4 cup of semi-sweet chocolate chip. Mix til smooth. Put in piping bag. Pipe an amount around the the edge of the cookie then fill the Center with 1/4 tsp of raspberry jam. Delicious!

I made these cookies and they were delicious! I had dried blueberries I wanted to use so I added about a cup of them to these cookies. I also added about a teaspoon of fresh lemon zest. They were soooo much better than plain sugar cookies. I decorated them with royal icing. For strength, I made them 14 inch thick. I use bands that are placed on the ends of the rolling pin to ensure. These bands are the key to getting a very professional look and uniform thickness. Because of the thicker size, I cooked them until golden on the bottom, about 12 minutes.
Delicious and will definetly make it again
Cakiest cookie ever. No thanks
PERFECTION!!! Don’t change a thing!!!
I added more sugar, but cookie was dry and tasteless. I will go back to my original cream cheese sugar cookie that uses butter flavored shortening and butter.

I will definitely make this recipe again, but there were a few adjustments I made. First, I added more vanilla about a TBSP) and less almond extract, simply based on my flavor preference, and I also added about a 1/2 c more sugar and an extra ounce (about 4 oz total) of cream cheese after reading another review that the recipe was bland. I also did not add as much flour as it called for because I often find sugar cookies too dry. I mixed until the dough looked dry, not sticky, but not overly floury. Finally, we did not use them for cutouts so I cannot attest to how they would work with cookie cutters. We rolled them into little balls and dipped them in different sprinkles, then baked. They were amazing! They are so soft and they have a wonderful flavor, sweet, but not too sweet, and the cream cheese adds a subtle richness to the overall taste. I will definitely make these again. Maybe next time I'll try them with cutouts, but I will likely need to use more flour for cutouts.
not the best sugar cookies that I have ever made. they were ok, kind of disappointed

Outstanding recipe. Don't neglect the chilling step. I chill the dough wrapped in plastic wrap and pressed into a pancake shape because it's pretty hard to roll once its chilled. I like these cookies thick and with buttercream frosting.

I was surprised at how delicious these were! I love baking cookies but sugar cookies have always caused me stress because I couldn't get them right or find a recipe that was acceptable. I was skeptical about them at first because there are no leavening ingredients, but it turns out this is great because they hold their shape perfectly. I usually prefer a softer sugar cookie and was concerned about the 1/8" thickness but they were the perfect Christmas cookie texture (it turns out soft cookies probably weren't ideal anyway). The dough was such a beautiful consistency after rolling it out that I actually picked it up to show my mother. They cooked evenly, didn't spread, and didn't brown too quickly to catch. I gave it 4 stars because I did not follow the recipe perfectly and I think my decision to not do so was correct. I put a full tsp of vanilla extract instead of 1/2. The almond extract added a very nice and subtle flavor, but (in my opinion) it would have been too front-and-center if it had a 1:1 ratio with the vanilla, or worse yet the cookies would not be very flavorful. SAVING THIS RECIPE. THANK YOU FOR SHARING IT!

With a few changes (mentioned by so many in the reviews), these cookies were easy to make, easy to work with, and absolutely delicious! In addition to the changes recommended, I also swapped mascarpone for the cream cheese. What a Holiday treat!
you can't chill very long, the cheese hardens the batter

I used the suggestions that Cherish made and they are a wow! I did roll some out, but then did the scoop and flatten on the cookie sheet when I got tired of doing the cutouts. Used a royal icing which was super easy and dipped the cookies in the different colors that I made. Great recipe. Lost the first dozen to my husband. Thanks so much for the recipe and suggestions.

Not my favourite. I thought I'd like this because of the good reviews and the fact that I love cheese, but it is very fiddly and sticky - even when it's cold. I found it much easier to work with at 1/4 in. instead of 1/8, and makes for a better icing cookie. I'll probably use another recipe next time.

Loved them! We can’t get enough:) soft , sweet enough and just right. I used 3oz of cream cheese and they came out great, I’d like to clarify that amount as it says 1 package - I haven’t found a 3oz package of cream cheese yet, so tonight we will test it with 8oz of cream cheese.

They turned out wonderful, i did make changes as per another baker. I added 1/2 cup more sugar and 8 oz cream cheese. They are so much better than regular sugar cookies and they are great even with out the icing. Love love them.
Ddidnt care much for the cream cheese flavor and they were too sticky too roll out (

Light, buttery, delicate flavor! 
We certainly prepare again:)
I have used this recipe for years & will continue to make them for our family cookie decorating tradition.
The best cutout cookies! We make them every year for the holidays!

I only rated 3 stars because of ALL of the adjustments needed. I read through the comments and others were right. The recipe is off. Making their adjustments & it is a WONDERFUL tasting cookie!!! 1 C real butter; 1 (8 oz) creme cheese block; 1+ 1/2 C sugar; 1 egg; 1 tsp vanilla; 1/2 tsp almond; 3+1/2 C flour; 1 tsp baking powder & I added 1/2 tsp salt (heightens ANY flavors added). Tasted wonderful and easy to work with. Haven't baked them yet, so I'm hoping they hold their shape well.
These cookies are delicious! I made them with the top reviewer's recommendations and they came out fabulous! These will be my go to sugar cookie recipe from now on!

Great recipe, not to sweet. I used the suggested changes of another user. I used 1 cup unsalted real butter, 8oz. of cream cheese, 1 1/2 cup sugar, 1 egg, 1 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp almond extract, 3 1/2 cup flour and 1 tsp baking powder. Very easy to work with and tasted great! Also separate dough into six flattened sections and wrapped in plastic wrap to refrigerate. I used a 50/50 mix of powdered sugar and flour when rolling out.

I have been using this recipe for years, very soft and not too sweet...I make a cookie pizza using this recipe for the crust..just line a pizza pan with foil and put some baking spray on it and pat out the dough like a crust...some red royal icing for sauce, let dry..thensmear a little cream cheese icing here and there...cut out fruit leather for pepperoni, cut some gummies to look like green pepper,onion, etc...total sugar high, but the kids love it

I operated a cookie bakery for many years This was my go to sugar cookie cut out recipe except I doubled the recipe and used a full 8 oz bar of cream cheese and always used butter no margarine. I always got rave reviews on my cookies and even though I don't have my bakery anymore it is still my one and only recipe I use for sugar cut out cookies
The perfect sugar cookie recipe! Thanks.!!
Love these!

This may be the first successful sugar cookie I have ever made. I have a new oven, so the bake time requires some work, but the cookie taste was wonderful. I didn't have almond, I just went with what I had. I never use anything but real butter. I made them in my food processor. It handled it just fine with just a litle prodding, but I would split the dough if I were to make a larger batch. I'm not a baker, so I followed the instructions mostly. I did roll, but will use parchment paper in the future, or flatten small scoops with a walnut or a fork. I love the idea that the dough can be frozen for later. I think I might keep these on hand. I almost grabbed a pre-made roll at the supermarket, but I followed through with my vow to work until I could make good cookies. I don't think I need to go any farther, but I have new confidence for trying out a few more baked goods recipes. I'm going to read over the comments when I do - they are all so helpful. Thanks to everyone.
I am giving up on sugar cookies. This cream cheese recipe was my last attempt. They just have no flavor. Recipe was easy but the flavor just wasn't there.

With all of our changes - this is as an option - I used Lemon Extract for a fresh PoP of flavor to the Cream Cheese - worked very nicely! ALSO, divide into 3 - wrap & press into a thin "saucer" plate size portion & stick in the freezer - once firm - roll 1 at a time - delicious cookie without icing! (forgo the 8 hour chill time too!)

They didn't even last a day my son and his girlfriend ate them all before his oldest brother could get any! They are really good and they don't get hard like some cookies try them you won't regret it!

This is a terrific cookie! I used three different recipes during a recent baking-marathon, and this cookie had the best flavor and texture. It is a soft dough, so be sure to chill it for at least a few hours or overnight, roll small, chilly amounts of it with a dusting of flour and between parchment paper - and don't overwork it. The cookies baked nicely for me at 350* for 13-15 minutes - and were easily decorated with colored sugars, stiff buttercream frosting and/or royal icing.

I found this dough extremely difficult to work with. I made the dough and chilled it, of course. I divided it into small section thinking to keep the other sections chilled while I rolled out and cut the section i was working on. I actually had to roll it out, chill it AGAIN, then cut it, then chill it again...it took me HOURS of work because I had to re-chill the dough in between each step for each cookie. The flavor was pretty good, but not worth that Herculean amount of effort. My house is warmish, but not a sauna! It shouldn't have been that difficult to work with.
I made these for a cookie exchange and the texture of the dough was perfect.
I've only tasted these. Looking forward to making them one day!
Even after chilling the dough for over 24 hours it was still too sticky to roll out. I'll stick to simpler sugar cookie recipes.
by far best cookie and stays soft and flaky after couple days in storage.

FANTASTIC cookies. These are by far my new favorite sugar cookie. They rolled out perfectly and taste delicious. The almond and vanilla extract make them more of an "adult" tasting cookie (in my opinion). I made all snowflakes and am going to try to make them look like the ones in the picture and give them out as hostess gifts. I will definitely use this recipe again. I did make some MODIFICATIONS based on another review. I used 8 ounces of cream cheese, 1 1/2 cup sugar, 1 cup of real, unsalted butter, 1 egg, 1 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp almond extract, 3 1/2 cup flour and 1 tsp baking powder. Thank you for sharing.

This recipe is from the 1950s (?) Betty Crocker cookie cookbook that has been around for a long time. It never disappoints. I always get compliments on the cookies especially when I use a little more almond and and they roll out nice & thin . They do cook better on the air-bake cookie sheets.
The title itself sounded terrific. I made these for Christmas and was disappointed. I didn't short the sugar, but didn't get the sugar cookie taste.

I love this recipe!! The only thing I did because I’m adventurous is I did half sugar and half brown sugar and did a full table spoon of almond extract. Other than that the only complaint I had was after letting it refrigerate it was a tad hard to roll out.

These were absolutely amazing! The flavor was fabulous as was the texture. And these things STAYED MOIST FOREVER. No joke- I, in a moment of what I can only call an embarrassing moment of extreme weakness, came across two of these babies in a ziplock bag after coming back from vacation. They were almost two weeks old and- no joke- soft as the day they were baked. Definitely a keeper!
I have been making cookies over 20 years. This by far, is my husband's favorite recipe. I can't keep enough on hand. Plus, our granddaughter tries to beat papa to them

I tried it using the original recipe as written and found cookie nice & soft but agree that the cream cheese flavor is drab with cookie an overwhelming taste flour. I will try it again following tips others made.
Absolutely addictive!! I didn't have any cream cheese at hand so I used sour cream instead. Worked just fine and very delicious!

Cream Cheese Sugar Cookies
I think this recipe is great. I will say I find it best to divide the dough into four equal parts and wrap tightly with plastic wrap then let set in the fridge. I find the process of cutting, and decorating sugar cookies very time consuming, but I do enjoy it. The cookies have a very light flavor. If you are new at baking sugar cookies the first time it might be a trial and error experience like mine.?? I tried the bagged sugar cookie mix once. Yuck! Never again. This recipe is a keeper for me.
this recipe is delicious and my son even likes it and he doesn't like most things that are baked.My daughter is using it for her class for a party
Soft and delicious!
I made these cookies for my granddaughter's birthday. All the adults loved them and wanted the recipe!!!
Amazing!
I made these today and they were a big hit with everyone who has had some. I suspect they won't last long.

Made it exactly as is....perfect! Rolled them thicker and used cookie cutters. Brushed with egg whites and sprinkled with decorative sugar before baking. They are not too sweet, great flavor--not your normal sugar cookie. Will definitely make again!!

Excellent cookie recipe, it was just what I was looking for. It makes soft cookies that aren't too sweet that melt in your mouth. I did change the recipe slightly. I double the recipe because I used 8 oz of cheese instead of 3 oz and I didn't put salt in the cookies. The dough I made was perfect after 8 hours in the fridge. I let the dough thaw a little so it was easier to roll out for about 30 minutes. The cookies cut-out nicely and didn't need to flour the rolling pin. I baked my cookies until I saw a golden edge appear in the oven around 8-9 minutes in the oven @ 375 degrees. All I have to say is I made over 30 cookies and they were mostly gone with a day and half. Definitely recommend this recipe to anyone.
Made these for church yesterday's and I'm not thrilled with the recipe. These had no flavor to them. If I ever make them again then I would add more extract and more sugar
Fantastic recipes, my daughter loved it!!!

This is a fantastic recipe, and will be my go-to sugar cookie. I love the texture--just a little soft, but still holds up well after being cut into snowflakes and other shapes that break fairly easily. I read the other reviews that said it lacked in flavor, and in turn doubled the amount of vanilla and almond extracts. This was spot on; I ended up with a very flavorful cookie. I also rolled the dough to 1/4" thickness rather than 1/8" and baked slightly longer since I like my cookies a little thicker. They also did not spread very much while baking.

I've been making this recipe for years! Like some others I use real unsalted butter, 8oz cream cheese, 3/4 tsp almond extract, 1 tsp real vanilla extract, 3 1/2 cups flour & 1 tsp baking powder. I chill it overnight. They are perfect! The icing I use is 6 cups confectioners sugar, 1/4 c light corn syrup, 2 tsp almond extract & assorted gel food coloring. I have 2 girls in their 20's & my youngest girl is 17 & they still can't wait to make these every Christmas!
